content.webTitle: Rashford at Ronaldo level after 150 Manchester United games, says Solskjær

fields.headline: Rashford at Ronaldo level after 150 Manchester United games, says Solskjær
fields.bodyText: Ole Gunnar Solskjær believes Marcus Rashford is on the same level as Cristiano Ronaldo and Wayne Rooney were when they had played 150 times for Manchester United. Rashford marked his landmark appearance with arguably the finest goal of his career in Saturday’s 2-1 win over Brighton & Hove Albion at Old Trafford, a strike deriving from impressive close control and a curled finish from a tight angle. It was his 41st goal for the club, with Ronaldo having registered 25 times and Rooney 45 times after 150 games. Rashford is the youngest of the trio to reach the number of appearances. Asked if Rashford is at the level of Ronaldo and Rooney, Solskjær said: “Yes. Definitely he can be absolutely top-class. He is only 21 but the maturity he is showing at times is more than 21 and his work rate.” The defeat of Brighton was United’s seventh consecutive win from Solskjær’s opening seven games as interim manager with Rashford scoring five times in that sequence. “The more you score the more you believe you are going to score,” the Norwegian said. “The more you score the more chance you have of being confident, running into the same positions. The way he works during the week is fantastic because he practises a lot.” Towards the end Rashford drew a booking for a heavy tackle on Martín Montoya, having taken a painful challenge from the same player moments before. Solskjær pointed to the toughness of the Wythenshawe-born Rashford. “He is a proper Manc. You can’t kick him and keep him down. He will stand up for a fight and stand up for himself and a teammate. It is a pleasure working with him,” he said. The victory gave Solskjaer six wins from his opening six Premier League matches, drawing him level with Pep Guardiola and Carlo Ancelotti as the best start to a tenure in the competition. Paul Pogba opened the scoring with a penalty but Pascal Gross struck a late Brighton consolation, making it 2-1 with 18 minutes to go, and Ashley Young believes United should be more ruthless. “We can be even more clinical,” the captain said. “Being 2-0 up, we’ve got to be more ruthless to go and get the third, to go and get the fourth, to kill the game off, and then we can start keeping the ball more. We didn’t do that. They obviously got the goal and there was 15 minutes of defending.”
